evaluationWindow.description:
A time window is specified to match when at least one of the cases matches true. This is a sliding window
and evaluates in real time.

keepAlive.description:
Once a signal is generated, the signal will remain “open” if a case is matched at least once within
this keep alive window.

A signal will “close” regardless of the query being matched once the time exceeds the maximum duration.
This time is calculated from the first seen timestamp.

schema.description: Response with a list of incidents.

attributes.description: The incident's attributes from a response.

created.description: Timestamp when the incident was created.

customer_impact_duration.description: Length of the incident's customer impact in seconds. Equals the difference between `customer_impact_start` and `customer_impact_end`.

customer_impact_end.description: Timestamp when customers were no longer impacted by the incident.

customer_impact_scope.description: A summary of the impact customers experienced during the incident.

customer_impact_start.description: Timestamp when customers began being impacted by the incident.

customer_impacted.description: A flag indicating whether the incident caused customer impact.

detected.description: Timestamp when the incident was detected.

additionalProperties.description: Dynamic fields for which selections can be made, with field names as keys.

oneOf.description: A field with a single value selected.

type.description: Type of the single value field definitions.

value.description: The single value selected for this field.

oneOf.description: A field with potentially multiple values selected.

type.description: Type of the single value field definitions.

value.description: The multiple values selected for this field.

items.description: A value which has been selected for the parent field.

fields.description: A condensed view of the user-defined fields attached to incidents.

modified.description: Timestamp when the incident was last modified.

notification_handles.description: Notification handles that will be notified of the incident during update.

items.description: A notification handle that will be notified during incident update.

postmortem_id.description: The UUID of the postmortem object attached to the incident.

public_id.description: The monotonically increasing integer ID for the incident.

resolved.description: Timestamp when the incident's state was set to resolved.

time_to_detect.description: The amount of time in seconds to detect the incident. Equals the difference between `customer_impact_start` and `detected`.

time_to_internal_response.description: The amount of time in seconds to call incident after detection. Equals the difference of `detected` and `created`.

time_to_repair.description: The amount of time in seconds to resolve customer impact after detecting the issue. Equals the difference between `customer_impact_end` and `detected`.

time_to_resolve.description: The amount of time in seconds to resolve the incident after it was created. Equals the difference between `created` and `resolved`.

title.description: The title of the incident, which summarizes what happened.

relationships.description: The incident's relationships from a response.

get.description:
List endpoint returns logs that match a log search query.
[Results are paginated][1].

Both this endpoint and the POST endpoint can be used interchangeably when listing
logs.

**If you are considering archiving logs for your organization,
consider use of the Datadog archive capabilities instead of the log list API.
See [Datadog Logs Archive documentation][2].**

[1]: /logs/guide/collect-multiple-logs-with-pagination
[2]: https://docs.datadoghq.com/logs/archives

parameters.description:
For customers with multiple indexes, the indexes to search
Defaults to '*' which means all indexes
parameters.name: filter[index]

parameters.description: List following results with a cursor provided in the previous query.
parameters.name: page[cursor]

parameters.description: Maximum number of logs in the response.
parameters.name: page[limit]

schema.description: Response object with all logs matching the request and pagination information.

data.description: Array of logs matching the request.

items.description: Object description of a log after being processed and stored by Datadog.

attributes.description: JSON object containing all log attributes and their associated values.
JSON object of attributes from your log.

host.description: Name of the machine from where the logs are being sent.

message.description:
The message [reserved attribute](https://docs.datadoghq.com/logs/log_collection/#reserved-attributes)
of your log. By default, Datadog ingests the value of the message attribute as the body of the log entry.
That value is then highlighted and displayed in the Logstream, where it is indexed for full text search.

service.description:
The name of the application or service generating the log events.
It is used to switch from Logs to APM, so make sure you define the same
value when you use both products.

status.description: Status of the message associated with your log.

tags.description: Array of tags associated with your log.

next.description:
Link for the next set of results. Note that the request can also be made using the
POST endpoint.

meta.description: The metadata associated with a request

after.description:
The cursor to use to get the next results, if any. To make the next request, use the same.
parameters with the addition of the `page[cursor]`.

warnings.description:
A list of warnings (non fatal errors) encountered, partial results might be returned if
warnings are present in the response.

items.description: A warning message indicating something that went wrong with the query

code.description: A unique code for this type of warning

detail.description: A detailed explanation of this specific warning

title.description: A short human-readable summary of the warning

**If you are considering archiving logs for your organization,
consider use of the Datadog archive capabilities instead of the log list API.
See [Datadog Logs Archive documentation][2].**

[1]: /logs/guide/collect-multiple-logs-with-pagination
[2]: https://docs.datadoghq.com/logs/archives

schema.description: The request for a logs list.

filter.description: The search and filter query settings

from.description: The minimum time for the requested logs, supports date math and regular timestamps

indexes.description: For customers with multiple indexes, the indexes to search. Defaults to ['*'] which means all indexes.

items.description: The name of a log index.

query.description: The search query - following the log search syntax.

to.description: The maximum time for the requested logs, supports date math and regular timestamps

options.description:
Global query options that are used during the query.
Note: You should only supply timezone or time offset but not both otherwise the query will fail.

timeOffset.description: The time offset (in seconds) to apply to the query.

timezone.description: The timezone can be specified both as an offset, for example: "UTC+03:00".

cursor.description: List following results with a cursor provided in the previous query.

limit.description: Maximum number of logs in the response.

schema.description: Response object with all logs matching the request and pagination information.

data.description: Array of logs matching the request.

items.description: Object description of a log after being processed and stored by Datadog.

attributes.description: JSON object containing all log attributes and their associated values.
JSON object of attributes from your log.

host.description: Name of the machine from where the logs are being sent.

message.description:
The message [reserved attribute](https://docs.datadoghq.com/logs/log_collection/#reserved-attributes)
of your log. By default, Datadog ingests the value of the message attribute as the body of the log entry.
That value is then highlighted and displayed in the Logstream, where it is indexed for full text search.

service.description:
The name of the application or service generating the log events.
It is used to switch from Logs to APM, so make sure you define the same
value when you use both products.

status.description: Status of the message associated with your log.

tags.description: Array of tags associated with your log.

next.description:
Link for the next set of results. Note that the request can also be made using the
POST endpoint.

meta.description: The metadata associated with a request

after.description:
The cursor to use to get the next results, if any. To make the next request, use the same.
parameters with the addition of the `page[cursor]`.

warnings.description:
A list of warnings (non fatal errors) encountered, partial results might be returned if
warnings are present in the response.

items.description: A warning message indicating something that went wrong with the query

code.description: A unique code for this type of warning

detail.description: A detailed explanation of this specific warning

title.description: A short human-readable summary of the warning
title.example: One or several indexes are missing or invalid, results hold data from the other indexes

get.description: List rules.

condition.description:
A rule case contains logical operations (`>`,`>=`, `&&`, `||`) to determine if a signal should be generated
based on the event counts in the previously defined queries.

notifications.description: Notification targets for each rule case.

createdAt.description: When the rule was created, timestamp in milliseconds.

creationAuthorId.description: User ID of the user who created the rule.

isDefault.description: Whether the rule is included by default.

isDeleted.description: Whether the rule has been deleted.

evaluationWindow.description:
A time window is specified to match when at least one of the cases matches true. This is a sliding window
and evaluates in real time.

keepAlive.description:
Once a signal is generated, the signal will remain “open” if a case is matched at least once within
this keep alive window.

maxSignalDuration.description:
A signal will “close” regardless of the query being matched once the time exceeds the maximum duration.
This time is calculated from the first seen timestamp.

queries.description: Queries for selecting logs which are part of the rule.

distinctFields.description: Field for which the cardinality is measured. Sent as an array.

metric.description:
The target field to aggregate over when using the sum or max
aggregations.

query.description: Query to run on logs.

meta.description: Object describing meta attributes of response.

total_filtered_count.description: Total count of elements matched by the filter.

tags.description:
All requests to Datadog’s API must be authenticated.
Requests that write data require reporting access and require an `API key`.
Requests that read data require full access and also require an `application key`.

**Note:** All Datadog API clients are configured by default to consume Datadog US site APIs.
If you are on the Datadog EU site, set the environment variable `DATADOG_HOST` to
`https://api.datadoghq.eu` or override this value directly when creating your client.

[Manage your account’s API and application keys](https://app.datadoghq.com/account/settings#api).

## Validate API key

[See API version 1](/api/v1/authentication/#validate-api-key).
tags.name: Authentication

tags.description:
**Note: This endpoint is in public beta. If you have any feedback, contact [Datadog support](https://docs.datadoghq.com/help/).**

To grant read access on log data at all, you must grant the `logs_read_data` permission.
From there you can limit what data a role grants read access to by associating a Restriction Query with that role.

A Restriction Query is a logs query that restricts which logs the `logs_read_data` permission grants read access to.
For users whose roles have Restriction Queries, any log query they make only returns those log events that also match
one of their Restriction Queries. This is true whether the user queries log events from any log-related feature, including
the log explorer, Live Tail, re-hydration, or a dashboard widget.

Restriction Queries currently only support use of the following components of log events:

- Reserved attributes
- The log message
- Tags

The recommended way to manage restricted read access on log data for customers with large or complicated organizational structures
is to add a team tag to log events to indicate which team(s) own(s) them, and then to scope Restriction Queries to the appropriate
values of the team tag. Tags can be applied to log events in many ways, and a log event can have multiple tags with the same key (like team)
and different values—in this way the same log event can be visible to roles whose restriction queries are scoped to different team values.

You need an API and application key with Admin rights to interact with this endpoint.
tags.name: Logs Restriction Queries

tags.description: The processes API allows you to query processes data for your organization.
tags.name: Processes

tags.description:
The Roles API is used to create and manage Datadog roles, what
[global permissions](https://docs.datadoghq.com/account_management/rbac/)
they grant, and which users belong to them.

Permissions related to specific account assets can be granted to roles
in the Datadog application without using this API. For example, granting
read access on a specific log index to a role can be done in Datadog from the
[Pipelines page](https://app.datadoghq.com/logs/pipelines).
tags.name: Roles
